# How to Find Email Addresses (2K+ Free Credits Inside)â€‹


# How to Find Email Addresses (2K+ Free Credits Inside)â€‹

â€¢ Free email finders and how to use them
â€¢ 1. What options you can set for an email search
â€¢ 2. Install Chrome extensions to find email addresses outside the apps
â€¢ 3. What types of email addresses you can find
â€¢ 4. Use a company email format finder in case the data is missing
â€¢ 5. Check the data accuracy with email verifiers
â€¢ 6. What else you can learn about your email prospects
â€¢ 7. Speed things up with bulk email finders
â€¢ 8. Request the data via an email lookup API
â€¢ 9. How much itâ€™ll cost you to find email addresses
â€¢ How to find email addresses yourself, without lookup tools
â€¢ Final Word
Whatâ€™s the easiest way toÂ find someoneâ€™s email address? The first thing that usually comes to mind is checking their contact page.
Sounds logical.
This is what that page is for, after all. But what if all it has is a generic email likeÂ info@domain.com? Sending messages, especially marketing pitches, there feels like throwing them into a black hole. Unless you offer a six-figure paycheck, of course. ğŸ™‚
Then, how about visiting their team page that should reveal more info about employees, including their email addresses?
Makes sense.
> But I checked around 1,3K team pages during my lastÂ email search, and only 11% of them had employeesâ€™ contact details. In 89% of cases, I was out of luck. Thatâ€™s what you should expect too, give or take.
But I checked around 1,3K team pages during my lastÂ email search, and only 11% of them had employeesâ€™ contact details. In 89% of cases, I was out of luck. Thatâ€™s what you should expect too, give or take.
The good thing is anÂ email searchÂ doesnâ€™t end on contact and team pages.
Although people are cagey about any personal info today, it still surfaces here and there on the web.Â Some companies collect that data into email lists fromÂ Facebook groups or pages, blog posts, and many other places to further share it with their customers viaÂ email finder tools.
LearnÂ how to find email addresses, both with the help of such tools and other tricks you didnâ€™t think of before. Not only will youÂ improve email deliverabilityÂ (a very critical thing) but also will have more responses in your inbox at the end of the day.

## Free email finders and how to use them

Letâ€™s start withÂ email finders, as they can let you do the job much quicker than a manual search. No web browsing for hours. The whole process comes down to typing in a few words like your prospectâ€™s name or their domain or both.
Thereâ€™s no shortage ofÂ email finding toolsÂ on the market for sure. Some require a paid subscription only, while others offer some sort of a freebie:
â€¢ a free plan where email search credits get renewed every month;
â€¢ a trial with a limited amount of free credits given one time only.
Like I said in the title, this post includes only tools providing free credits. In total, youâ€™ll get 2,288 credits at no cost (1,873 per month and 415 for once).
WhileÂ email lookup toolsÂ work the same way, their feature packs still differ. Imagine how much time it takes to test them all yourself and filter out those that lack necessary functionalities. Itâ€™d keep you up late, right?
To save you long hours of testing, I took it upon myself. Below, you can learn about the major features and how they differ in each tool on my list.

## 1. What options you can set for an email search

In email prospecting, you can find yourself at different stages.
Sometimes, you know your prospectâ€™s full name and employer. Other times, you only have a list of companies to connect with but have no idea whom to contact there.
To get you covered in any circumstances,Â email findersÂ provide various search options.
Email search by nameÂ and company (or domain)
> This option will come in handy when you have a clear idea of who your prospect is and where they work.
This option will come in handy when you have a clear idea of who your prospect is and where they work.
ToÂ discover their email address, type in both their full name and company (or its domain).
Example of how to find email addresses by name and company from GetProfiles
Email search by companyÂ (or domain) only
> Do you know the company you want to collaborate with but arenâ€™t sure about the best person to reach out to?
Do you know the company you want to collaborate with but arenâ€™t sure about the best person to reach out to?
Then, this option is for you.
Type in your target companyâ€™s name (or its domain), and youâ€™ll see all the employees available in the toolâ€™s database, along with their emails and oftentimes job titles.
Example of how to find email addresses by domain from Email Discovery Tool
The cool thing is it usually costs a single credit to check many emails under the same domain.
Email search by nameÂ only
> With this option, you canÂ find someoneâ€™s email addressÂ by their first and last names.
With this option, you canÂ find someoneâ€™s email addressÂ by their first and last names.
Itâ€™s convenient, as you may not always know where your prospect works at the moment.
For example, you might have found them on the page of 2017. Back then, they represented Apple but could have switched jobs over the last three years.
It can hardly make any sense to look up emails by their name and the company they worked for a few years ago. Thatâ€™s why some email finders let you leave out employer details.
Example of how to find email addresses by name from RocketReach
What if your preferred tool lacks such an option? Check your prospectâ€™s current employer on LinkedIn beforehand.
Email search by city, address, and prospectâ€™s other details
To narrow down your search, some email finder tools provide a bunch of extra filters.
Letâ€™s say you are at an early stage of email prospecting. You still wonder what companies to contact but have a clear understanding of their location, industry, size, revenue, and stuff like that.
By mentioning any of these search criteria, youâ€™ll get more relevant results.
Example of extra email search options from LeadMine
Here are 30 email finders compared by their search criteria and filters.

## 2. Install Chrome extensions to find email addresses outside the apps

In the first place,Â email search toolsÂ are available as web apps but many of them also come packed with extensions, mostly for Chrome.
With their help, you wonâ€™t have to switch between your app interface and other open tabs all the time.
Just click the extension icon in your browser toÂ discover emailsÂ from wherever you are. It can be your prospectâ€™s site, social profile, or even Google search results.
Kudos to someone whoâ€™s come up with such a clever idea and others whoâ€™ve shamelessly replicated it!
Kudos aside,Â email finder extensionsÂ can expand your search with a few more options. Here they are.
Social media email search
Itâ€™s perfect for those of you who want toÂ find someoneâ€™s email on LinkedIn, Facebook, or Twitter.
When you enter your prospectâ€™s social profile, click the extension icon and wait a few secs for their address to show up.
Example of how to find someoneâ€™s email on LinkedIn from Slik
Example of how to find someoneâ€™s email on Facebook from SignalHire
Example of how to find someoneâ€™s email on Twitter from Prophet II Turbo
Besides extensions, this option is sometimes built right intoÂ email finder apps. To perform a search, copy and paste someoneâ€™s social URL into the app dashboard.
Example of how to find emails by social URL from FindThatLead
There are some Chrome extensions, such asÂ LeadDelta, that can help you organize your existing Linkedin contacts by bringing them all into a single-view table (CRM).
Besides useful options like tagging, filtering, and sending personalized messages, it also allows you to auto-unlock and export your connectionsâ€™ information such as email, phone, industry, and more.
On-siteÂ email search
Ever found yourself on a website showing high potential and got curious about their contact person?
No need to start a new search for that.
On click, youâ€™llÂ find email addresses from websitesÂ straight away, while youâ€™re on them.
Example of how to find all email addresses on a website from Adapt
Google email search
Your prospects are people involved in your field in one way or another. Logically, content on their sites should match your strategic search queries.
This option can make your email prospecting on Google easier.
When you check sites ranking for your queries, it lets youÂ extract their emails from Google searchÂ along the way.
Example of how to find email addresses on Google from Snovio
Feel free to compareÂ email finder extensionsÂ by their search options and popularity.

## 3. What types of email addresses you can find

Generally, all you need is your prospectâ€™s business email. But there are cases when things turn out more complicated than they seem to be.
Thatâ€™s why such tools let you search forÂ different types of email addresses.
Personal email search
Personal email addressesÂ arenâ€™t tied to company domains. Instead, they come from Gmail, Yahoo, and other free webmail providers.
Example of how to find personal email addresses from ContactOut
Wonder why you may need toÂ find someoneâ€™s personal email?
Imagine that your prospect quit their job at the company where you found them but didnâ€™t indicate that on LinkedIn.
Not sure about you but I canâ€™t think of any other way to learn about their job change.
If youÂ search for their email address by nameÂ and domain, your tool will return you their old business email thatâ€™s already inactive. Even if itâ€™s not yet, you can hardly expect a reply from there.
While business emails come and go, personal addresses remain with us regardless of our employers.
Does it mean you should contact your prospects via their personal emails only?
Definitely not.
But every time no one opens your message from their business address, try to resend it to the personal one.
Business email search
Business email addressesÂ are tied to domains that your prospects use on behalf of their companies.
They should be your top priority except for the force majeure cases when thereâ€™s no info about someoneâ€™s current employment.
Example of how to find business email addresses from VoilaNorbert
GenericÂ email search
Generic email addressesÂ are tied to company domains, but not to someone specific on the team (contact@domain.com, info@domain.com).
Such addresses are also called â€œrole-based,â€ as they often indicate departments (marketing@domain.com, sales@domain.com, support@domain.com).
Example of how to find generic email addresses from Finder.Expert
Note that you should turn to them only as a last resort when you canâ€™tÂ find business email addresses. But life is pain, and I have to admit that youâ€™ll have no other choice at times.
Learn what types of email addresses each tool on my list can help you find.

## 4. Use a company email format finder in case the data is missing

Email lookup toolsÂ arenâ€™t magic wands, and they wonâ€™t provide the data in 100% of your requests. Thatâ€™s especially common to new hires, as their addresses donâ€™t appear in the tool database overnight.
What can help you figure them out is anÂ email format finder. It will show you the most common email format used at your target company.
Example of how to find a company email address format from LeadGibbon
Then, you can manually check if your prospect has an email formatted that way too.
Enter it into your mailbox address field to see if there appears a pic on hover. If it does, someone must have added it, so that email should be in use.
Note that some tools reveal email formats in company directories. As a rule, you can access them from the footer.
Unfortunately, such a feature isnâ€™t available in too many tools on my list.

## 5. Check the data accuracy with email verifiers

UsingÂ email findersÂ is no doubt the quickest way to find contact details but you canâ€™t blindly trust everything they show.
Their owners donâ€™t even conceal the fact that they canâ€™t guarantee 100% email accuracy.
What they can do is send some tell-tale signs your way.
Email confidence score
The first metric toÂ check email accuracyÂ is a confidence score calculated in percent. It shows how reliable an email address is according to their estimates and checks.
Hereâ€™s how you can interpret the different scores you see.
â€¢ HighÂ means an email address is deliverable.
â€¢ AverageÂ means an email address is risky.
â€¢ LowÂ means an email address is undeliverable.
Example of an emailâ€™s confidence score from FindEmails
Email verificationÂ status
Another way to determine if an email address is valid is by checking its verification status. This status typically appears next to or instead of a confidence score, depending on the tool you use. For more advanced validation, you can go for API integration that provides real-time verification of email addresses.
WhenÂ verifying email addresses, youâ€™ll come across a few statuses.
â€¢ ValidÂ means an email address passed all their checks and is deliverable.
â€¢ Catch-allÂ (or accept-all) means an address is tied to one of those domains that accept all emails, whether you send them toÂ name.surname@domain.comÂ orÂ blahblahblah@domain.com. Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s impossible toÂ check email validityÂ in such cases.
â€¢ InvalidÂ means an email address failed to pass at least one check and is undeliverable.
Example of email verification statuses from Skrapp
Email verification process
ToÂ verify if an email exists, the system gives it multiple checks.
While each tool has its own verification algorithm, they commonly focus on the following aspects.
â€¢ Domain Type. The system makes sure an email isnâ€™t tied to one of those domains used for disposable addresses.
â€¢ Server Status. The system verifies MX records on your target domain and the possibility to connect to its SMTP server.
â€¢ Email Format. The system checks email syntax, whether itâ€™s valid (name.surname@domain.com)Â or looks like mumbo jumbo (1e99cs3bp7@domain.com).
â€¢ Email Status. The system tests whether an email can bounce and checks if the server has a catch-all policy.
Example of email validity checks from Hunter
StandaloneÂ email verifiers
When you perform an email search, youâ€™ll see its verification status right in yourÂ email finderÂ dashboard.
But things donâ€™t end there.
Some tools also provide standaloneÂ email verifiers. Theyâ€™ll come in handy if youâ€™ve already found contact details elsewhere and want to double-check them for validity.
Enter any email address you have, and the tool will verify if itâ€™s deliverable.
Example of a standalone email verifier from SellHack
Email address sources
Email lookup toolsÂ boast of having millions to billions of contacts in their indexes. But where does that data come from?
Unless an email is their best guess, they should have found it somewhere.
To prove their data reliability, some tools back it up with sources. These are URLs of pages where they discovered peopleâ€™s contact details.
At least, you can rest assured that their suggestions arenâ€™t taken out of nowhere.
ToÂ find the source of an email address, you donâ€™t need to perform any specific search. If your tool has such data, itâ€™ll appear next to emails.
Example of email address sources from MailDB
User rates
Wanna do a good deed and earn a few karma points?
Some tools involve their users inÂ email verification, so this is your chance. They provide an option allowing you to rate their suggestions.
If an email identified as valid bounced for you, feel free to report such a failure by downvoting it.
Example of how to rate email accuracy from Lusha
Hereâ€™s how the tools on my list differ in everything related to email verification.

## 6. What else you can learn about your email prospects

Email prospecting goes far beyond a search for contact details.
You do need toÂ find peopleâ€™s email addressesÂ to get in touch with them. But at the same time, it wonâ€™t hurt to dig deeper into their backgrounds and figure out a better approach to them.
For that reason, manyÂ email findersÂ reveal peopleâ€™s full or at least partial profiles. Itâ€™s quite convenient to explore additional details about them along with their emails, all in one place.
You can check anything from their personal data like social accounts, work experience, and skills to company information like size, HQ locations, and even phone numbers.
I donâ€™t advise that you contact people by phone, though.
Letâ€™s face it, the reputation of cold emails is anything but good. And what can be worse than sending cold emails is only making cold calls.
Example of an email prospect profile from GetProspect
Below, you can check what these tools include in their email prospect profiles.

## 7. Speed things up with bulk email finders

It doesnâ€™t take long toÂ check email addressesÂ when you have a dozen prospects or so.
But we donâ€™t run such small outreach campaigns as a rule, do we? If we did, how many responses would we get?
Guys from Mangools consider aÂ 16% response rateÂ to be a good result, and theyâ€™re absolutely right. With a dozen prospects, we could expect 1-2 responses.
Next to nothingâ€¦
With hundreds of prospects on the list, imagine how much time it drains to perform an individualÂ email searchÂ for everyone.
To put an end to this time-wasting, such tools provide aÂ bulk email finder.
Using this feature, you can upload many email requests in one go and then export results with a single click.
An hourâ€™s work comes down to minutes.
Example of how to find emails in bulk from ColdCRM
Email address verificationÂ can go in bulk too.
Did you get hundreds of addresses from God knows where? UseÂ bulk email verifiersÂ to check them all for validity in one go.
Example of how to verify email addresses in bulk from Find That Email
Learn what kind of email searches each tool lets you perform in bulk.

## 8. Request the data via an email lookup API

Good news for those of you who want toÂ find peopleâ€™s emailsÂ programmatically.
Most of the tools reviewed here provide an email lookup API. With its help, you can integrate their functionalities into your website, app, or CRM software and send email requests through API calls.

## 9. How much itâ€™ll cost you to find email addresses

Here comes the part that will determine your choice of anÂ email finder like nothing else.
Pricingâ€¦
All the tools on my list let youÂ search for emails for freeÂ to a certain degree. But still, if you have a crush on one of them and need more credits, you can subscribe to its premium package.
I compared their monthly prices for the cheapest plan along with the number of email credits available there. Thatâ€™s what a price per lookup is based on.
Note that someÂ free email findersÂ wonâ€™t let you in with your personal Gmail or Yahoo address. To sign up, youâ€™ll need to use a business, domain-based email only.
They had to set such a barrier due to long-term abuse of their free packages. Sounds kinda fair, doesnâ€™t it?

## How to find email addresses yourself, without lookup tools

Email address findersÂ are mighty, but they are by far not almighty.
People can hide their contact details so good that no email crawler will ever see a trace of them.
You can also run out of credits before you reach the bottom of your prospecting list. Can you wait for the end of the month, when your credits get renewed? I doubt it.
Here are a fewÂ ways to find email addressesÂ without lookup tools.

### 1. Find emails in source code

When yourÂ email huntÂ is on, the first place to go should be your prospectâ€™s site. But as I said earlier, contact and team pages donâ€™t always reveal email addresses.
If your prospect is an author of some blog post, scroll down to its bio section.
Nothing?
Try to hover your mouse over their name or any other snippet thatâ€™s hyperlinked. Sometimes, email addresses appear in bios but you canâ€™t see them with the naked eye.
Still nothing?
Then, you need to dig deeper into code. The question ofÂ how to find an email address in source codeÂ usually throws people into a panic. No worries, itâ€™s easy even for non-techies like me.
Right-click somewhere on the page and select â€œView page source.â€
Before you feel dizzy with what you see, click CTRL + F and type inÂ mailto:Â orÂ @domain.com. If thereâ€™s an email hidden in the page code, you should see it this way.

### 2. Find emails from websites via subscription

This trick isnâ€™t for people fed up with too many promos coming their way. â€˜Cause thereâ€™ll be even moreâ€¦
A lot of online newsletters come from peopleâ€™s business emails rather than generic addresses. No matter if itâ€™s an individual blog or corporate site. So, I suggest that you subscribe to your prospectâ€™s mailing list.
No luck?
Then, respond to a generic address likeÂ newsletter@domain.com, and you may hear back from a business email of someone on the team.
If you target a company offering a free product trial, sign up for it. Nine times out of ten, youâ€™ll get a message from their head of marketing or sales rep.
With this trick, the number of promos will grow in your inbox but better focus on the bright side. Your response rates will grow too.
In business, people are more willing to reply to their leads rather than strangers who donâ€™t give a damn about their products.

### 3. Guess email addresses based on common formats

Every time your tool returns nothing, you can try toÂ guess an email addressÂ yourself.
Business emails are commonly based on formats that include your prospectâ€™s domain and variations of their first and/or last names.
Here are the most popular email formats according toÂ Hunterâ€™s analysisÂ of 12 million addresses.
Substitute your prospectâ€™s details for the default values, as shown in the Example column, to come up with their possible emails. One of them should be valid.
To identify it, copy and paste them all into your Gmail address field. The one that shows a name or pic on hover should exist.
You can also check them one by one in Google using an exact-match search operator.
Unfortunately, it takes a while to create a lot of possible email addresses manually. WithÂ Email Permutator, you can skip such a monkey job.
Enter your prospectâ€™s full name and domain, and itâ€™ll generate many email variations automatically.
Example of business email address formats from Email Permutator
Next, youâ€™ll need to check if theyâ€™re valid, though.
If you donâ€™t even want to bother with that, installÂ Name2EmailÂ in Chrome. This is aÂ completely free email lookupÂ extension.
Itâ€™ll generate possible emails right in your Gmail address field and highlight the valid one in green.
Example of company email address formats from Name2Email

### 4. Search Google for email addresses using advanced operators

Email findersÂ mostly collect their data from the public web. Thatâ€™s what you can do too.
ToÂ search for an email address on Google, use itsÂ advanced operators. Here are examples of how to use them specifically for an email search.
â€¢ [name] + email
â€¢ [name] + email address
â€¢ [name] + contact
â€¢ [name] + contact info
â€¢ [name] + contact me
â€¢ site:domain.com + [name] + email
â€¢ site:domain.com + [name] + email address
â€¢ site:domain.com + [name] + contact
â€¢ site:domain.com + [name] + contact info
â€¢ site:domain.com + [name] + contact me
Should there be anything out in public, Google will bring it to the surface.

### 5. Run a Twitter email search

In moments of desperation, when emails donâ€™t show up anywhere, people request them on Twitter.
Go check if someone has asked such an awkward question for you and received the answer you need.
Hereâ€™s how.
Enter Twitterâ€™sÂ advanced search, add â€œemailâ€ or â€œcontactâ€ to the Words section and your prospectâ€™s user name to the Accounts section.
People often try to hide their contact details from email crawlers. Instead ofÂ name@domain.com, they can share their addresses this way:Â nameÂ atÂ domainÂ dotÂ com.
So, you can also specify â€œatâ€ or â€œdotâ€ in your search.

### 6. Perform a WHOIS email search when targeting website owners

WHOISÂ is a free service providing basic info about any domain, including its physical address and contact details.
Emails available there mostly belong to company owners. So, if your outreach request is meant for corporate blog editors, the service will be of no use to you.
Donâ€™t bother CEOs, especially of bigger companies, with link requests. Most of the time, they have more important issues to handle.
Note that aÂ WHOIS email lookupÂ wonâ€™t always work for you. Some businesses share generic addresses there, while others hide them from public view.

### 7. How to ask for email addresses yourself

Tried all the tricks but still nothing? Unless your prospects live in a cave, thereâ€™s no way they donâ€™t have an email.
You only have one option leftâ€¦ Ask yourself.
I know what you think: how can I ask someone for contact details when Iâ€™ve no idea how to contact them?
First, reach out to a generic email likeÂ info@domain.comÂ or use their contact form.
Donâ€™t disclose your offer right there. Simply ask about the best person to discuss it and how to get in touch with them.
As an alternative, you can request your prospectâ€™s email on Twitter.
Better tag them with your question rather than send a private message. Speaking from experience, thereâ€™s usually so much spam in the Twitter inbox at the end of the day. Your request can easily get lost in it.

## Final Word

Now that you knowÂ how to find email addresses, I hope for some responsibility on your part. Imagine that you and thousands of others sign up forÂ email findersÂ and spam the hell out of the same people.
The outcome?
Those people will insist that their contact details are deleted from email databases in no time. Please, donâ€™t provoke them to go underground. Itâ€™ll end badly for all of us.
If you need some help with your outreach pitches, follow thisÂ detailed guide.
I can hardly imagine you couldnâ€™tÂ find someoneâ€™s emailÂ with so many tools and tricks. But still, if you couldnâ€™t, let me know. Iâ€™ll try to figure out how to handle your specific case.
